ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, I d suggest that you try regular NEAT first, HyperNEAT may not be neccessary. HyperNEAT is a good choice if the inputs are hundreds or thousands in

Hi Peter, 

I'd suggest that you try regular NEAT first, HyperNEAT may not =
be neccessary. HyperNEAT is a good choice if the inputs are hundreds or tho=
usands in number and/or there is some obvious geometry in the input space t=
hat can be exploited by arranging the positions of the substrate nodes. For=
 financial applications I'd use a small set of inputs, but very preprocesse=
d data, like what most good custom indicators do, and regular NEAT. 

Peter=



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
>
> Peter=
,
> 
> I think you'd be better off familiarizing yourself with the details =
of 
> how HyperNEAT works. Novelty Search is a different algorithm altogeth=
er, 
> for a different class of problems. You probably should familiarize 
=
> yourself with the HyperNEAT algorithm before trying to design an 
> exper=
iment. The HyperNEAT user's page has a lot of really good 
> information: h=
ttp://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> 
> I'm not familiar w=
ith the EPlex's C++ framework, but SharpNEAT does 
> provide a GUI. However=
, it's more of an engineer's GUI, designed to 
> visualize your experiment =
after you set it up in code. I tend to find it 
> easier to just use SharpN=
EAT in a console application. I've written some 
> tutorials on how to crea=
te a SharpNEAT experiment:
> 
> http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutori=
al-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/
> 
> Hope that helps.
=
> 
> Sincerely,
> Wesley
>
